bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to John A. Ferrell, August 25, 1922

div1.p: Carter suggests several possible field studies on malaria.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to John A. Ferrell, August 25, 1922
div1.opener:
The New Charlotte Sanatorium
Charlotte, N. C.
New Glasgow, P O
Amherst County, Va
“Geddes” August 25,1922
Dr. John A Ferrell,
Director for the United States,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York, N Y
Dear Doctor Ferrell:
div1.p:
Your letter of July 26/22 addressed to me at Marion, N C just to
hand.

In answer to your request for suggestions of field studies or
demonstrations of malaria which it seems advisable to make, I would name the
following:
1. A study of the effect of impounding water on the incidence of malaria.

This study was begun in 1914 and carried on during 1915 and 1916 by La
Prince, Griffitts and myself. Some surveys, minor, but not without value,
have been made by Griffitts and myself since that time and the study/would suggested
be in continuation (completion?) of the work already done.

The problem is of much economic and sanitary importance and I think that
a moderate amount of work for not less than two years and a much smaller
amount, as inspection and observation only, continued for some years longer,
(how many I cannot say) would be well repaid.

I have been purposing, when I have a little more data on this subject and
some spare time, to write up the findings we have been able to arrive at so
far and especially to formulate the measures advisable for preventing, or at
least, minimising, malaria caused by making these large ponds. A good deal
of data for this purpose is already available and I hope to get a little
more this fall.

The general method of study for the first two years would be (a) select
Page - 2
The New Charlotte Sanatorium
Charlotte, N. C.
a location in which a large body of water will be impounded within a year
or two - a hydro-electric plant in the making is the best possible (b) make
a survey: (1) of the incidence of malaria in this section: (2) of the
Anopheles production, noting breeding places; species and prevalence in
residences.

These surveys should not only cover the flowage area of the purposed
pond, but should extend, roughly, a mile or mile and a half beyond the
flowage contour - indeed, the survey, especially as to the species of
Anapheles and the production in this area beyond the contour should be
especially full.

There is no need of including the whole of the area indicated in the
survey; this might involve a very large amount of work. It is sufficient
that cross-sections be taken, a half-mile to a mile wide, at suitable
places so as to sample the country we are investigating. This limitation
is especially advised for the Anopheles survey. The malaria survey is so
much easier made that this may, escept in very large ponds - that of Lock
17, Black Warrior - was over 65 miles long - be made to include all
people in the area indicated.

An examination of the same territory - after the poind pond is filled
and for as many years thereafter as may be necessary - should give us
data to determine the effect of the impounded water on the incidence of
malaria: Naturally, there are a number of other factors to be noted, but
this is the general plan.

Detail and modifications available of the above general plan should be
given only if this study be undertaken as it would involve sometime to
write them out.
Page - 3

The New Charlotte Sanatorium
Charlotte, N. C.

The above was what was planned and, more or less imperfectly, carried
out in 1915 and 1916

A working party should consist of a chief (man of status of Barber or
Griffitts) with two or three intelligent young men for helpers (students
on vacation are about the type needed) and a Ford automobile. This is for
the surveys of areas before the water is impounded. After the pond is
filled, the use of a motor boat - usually cheaply obtainable from the
Power Company - and one or two small skiffs or canoes are necessary in
addition. The skiffs should be furnished with Evenrude motors.

One such party should be able to examine for two large ponds and
transportation between them must be provided for several trips.

The work will last only during the season of contaminative Anopheles
production - May 1st - October 31st as a maximum; mainly from June 1st -
Oct 31st.

The cost I cannot estimate. A guess estimate would be about $12,500
to $15,000 each year for the first two years and about 67% to 50% of
that amount for - say five years thereafter - not necessarily consecutive
years.

The estimate is for one party with three assistants, working - the
chief twelve and the assistants 6 1/2 months.

It is possible enough that the intensive work outlined for the first
2 years would need to be repeated - so as to cover, at least, four large
ponds in which case the larger estimate should hold for four years.

p.hi: Study of Cypress Swamp Breeding of Anopheles

div1.p:
This involves, and unquestionably includes, a study of such breeding
at a distance from the blood-supply furnished by man and domestic
animals.
Page - 4

The New Charlotte Sanatorium
Charlotte, N. C.

I had purposed to take this up, in a small way, in 1917, but the war
prevented. It is of some importance, both from a scientific and a practical
standpoint, but especially from the former. Of much less importance than
(1), but is an absolutely untouched problem

Estimate of cost - about $12,500 to $15,000 per annum - or less - for
say - two years. Same field party as for Impounded Water, but no launch
needed.

3. To determine the different valencies in nature of our three principal
species of Anopheles as vectors of malaria.

Dr. Fricks is already working on this problem as regards the role of A.
punctipennis compared with the other two, but I am sure he would be glad
to be able to extend this work.

It is obviously most important. Indeed, I have considered it the most
important of the field problems of malaria yet unsolved, and have done some
epidemiological (field) work on it myself.

The methods and costs of carrying them out can be obtained from Dr.
Fricks better than from myself. The expense will depend, maturally, on the
extent to which the work is carried.

4. To study how best to combine control of malaria (control of Anopheles
production) with the large scale drainage projects for agriculture.

I think this is not the class of studies to which your letter refers.
It is, however, important and I am sure, feasible.

Obviously, both the efficacy of the Anopheles control and the economical
adaptation of the measures therefor to the drainage work, must be considered
It should begin by a preliminary study, in the field where drainage work is
going on, by a thoroughly competent malarial engineer in consultation with
a drainage engineer. During this, the measures tentatively agreed on by
Page - 5
The New Charlotte Sanatorium
Charlotte, N. C.
both as necessary to control Anopheles production and allowable from a
drainage standpoint could be checked up.

Practically the only expense for this preliminary work would be the pay of
the malaria engineer and his traveling expenses - for he should visit more
than one drainage project. It would need one of the very best of our engineers,
however.

If this should result in the general adoption of measures for the control of
Anopheles by drainage engineers, and it might well be an important step thereto,
its value would be very great. We have been trying since 1917 to get these men
interested in malaria control, so that the lands fitted for agriculture by
drainage might be, by the same measure, freed from malaria. This has not, by
any means, always been the case.

5. The repetition, in various places and times, of Mitzmain's work at Monroe,
La in 1917 to determine the last date in the fall at which Anopheles are in-
fective to men.

This is important, as giving us the date in the fall at which it is safe
to suspend oiling and other measures for the control of Anopheles production.
I think the saving to my Service in 1918, due to this knowledge, was not less
than $150,000.

This is a purely scientific study - partly field and partly bench - and a
working party should consist of one entomological microscopist and a helper.
More than one party can be used - and for several years.

This work, however, as it can be done for only about 1 month per annum in
any one district, had best be made a side issue to other work of the same kind -
such as Barber and Mayne are doing now. I doubt, then, if this fails in the
category of the class of studies you mean. I think not.
